> Although this would still be code modification... you could
> do it in TestNG with an 'ignore' annotation. As long as
> TestNG still reported it (e.g. as skipped, or as explicitly
> ignored), it shouldn't be forgotten.

Yup, that's one way. Another one is to create a group that is always
excluded from your test runs (sometimes, a test fails and I find that I
don't have the time to fix it just yet and I don't want the test runs to go
red for several days, so I need to disable it and make sure I don't forget
to turn it back on later).

I use the group name "broken" for that. Among the HTML reports generated by
TestNG is one that lists all the groups and test methods that belong to
them, so it's trivial to see what tests belong to the "broken" group.

> (In JUnit, one way to avoid forgetting is to comment out the
> body of the test, and then assert that the test is being run
> before a particular date.
> If you do forget, you automatically get a "wake up call" when
> the date is passed)

Interesting idea. It's too bad that it still requires active human
participation, though, so you make me wonder if it would make sense to
include such hint in the annotation itself:

@Test(enabled = false, reEnableBy("2005-06-02"))
public void insertIntoDataBase() {
...
}

and the framework would automatically ignore "enabled=false" after the given
date.

A bit convoluted but intriguing :-)
